content.description: The route follows a series of huecos up the face to a large ledge, then traverses over to the end of Cold Shut (5.8). The crux comes in the first ten feet, before the ledge. Very small footholds and slippery handholds (we did it while it was raining), along with mud on the ledge just compounds the difficulty of the route. IF TOPROPING WITH COLD SHUT ANCHOR: BE CAREFUL. ALL FALLS WILL SWING YOU BACK AGAINST THE WALL WHERE COLD SHUT IS!!!
content.protection: Same tree that you top rope from for Cold Shut. There's a crack system that you can follow for trad, along with some horizontal cracks.
content.location: The route starts in the large hueco across from the start of Cold Shut. Swing your  legs onto the rounded off edge and lay back the flake, then use the huecos from there for holds and footholds.

content.description: Quick line that we put up in the rain, using the trad gear for the first time. It's found at the end of the cliff, around the corner from End Wall (V1). follows a crack line up some crazy features eroded into the sandstone. The route starts in a little alcove that you have to pull yourself up into, then follows the fin to the left of the alcove.
content.protection: 7, 8, 9 Hexes. No anchors at the top, but you can walk off (kinda) or rappel from a tree or rhododendron.
content.location: To the right and around the corner from End Wall.

content.description: Easy route, a few pinches. The one rock looks sketchy, but in reality is very stable. most challenging part is popping up through the Rhododendron bush at the top of the route.
content.location: At the short end of the wall, where it makes a ninety degree angle before terminating against the hillside. Start at the corner, moving slightly left as you move up the route. Fairly obvious holds. Scramble down the side next to the end of the cliff to get down from a top out.

content.description: Be very careful. Some of the rock is very thin, but is trustable. You'll understand the name cold shut when you feel the air coming out of the crack. The hardest move is getting up over the overhang at the top of the cliff. You can go up on either side of it, but the real challenge comes going directly over it, as it has very small if any handholds.
content.protection: There are trees at the top to slingshot top rope from. Foliage at the top prevents direct top roping.
content.location: Follow the cliffline for about 10 yards where it recesses back into a small chimney. On the right is a small crack. You're going to pretty much be straddling the crack when you climb this route, until after the first two or three moves.

content.description: The start is where the rock looks near cut in half by a massive chimney. Definite route could be set here. This whole chimney has some pretty sweet features, but this particular route starts all the way to the back of the chimney, where there is a small ledge to start on. A little too high to do with just a pad. This is just an experimental project, so if anyone formulates a good route here, feel free to improve this route.
content.location: Follow the trail along the cliffs underneath the first roof to where it opens up to a large chimney. At the very back of the chimney is where the route starts. Top out to get down.

content.description: This crag is about a 50-75 yard stretch of cliff above the parking lot for the bike trail. Includes some very interesting features, as well as a small cave. Far left side is the best spot to climb, with some very stable, strange formations. Incredible area for toproping and highball bouldering. Second best wall in the gorge.
